title: 111_hr1326
content:
The Act is titled the "Great Ape Protection Act of 2009" and its purpose is outlined in Section 2 as findings and purpose. Congress finds that great apes are highly intelligent and social animals, and invasive research on them for economic purposes significantly impacts interstate commerce, particularly in the development of drugs and pharmaceuticals. The regulation of animals and activities under this Act is necessary to effectively regulate interstate and foreign commerce. The National Research Council report on chimpanzees in research emphasizes moral responsibility for their care, a moratorium on breeding, and avoiding euthanasia for population control. The Great Ape Protection Act aims to prohibit invasive research on great apes, their breeding for research purposes, and their transport for such research. It also requires lifetime care for federally owned apes in suitable sanctuaries. The Great Ape Protection Act aims to prohibit invasive research on great apes, their breeding for research purposes, and their transport for such research. It also requires lifetime care for federally owned apes in suitable sanctuaries. SEC. 3. DEFINITIONS. The term "great ape" in the Act includes chimpanzees, bonobos, gorillas, orangutans, or gibbons. "Invasive research" refers to any research that may harm or cause distress to a great ape, such as testing drugs or exposing them to harmful substances, invasive procedures, or restraining them. The term "great ape" includes chimpanzees, bonobos, gorillas, orangutans, or gibbons. Invasive research refers to any research that may harm or cause distress to a great ape, such as testing drugs or exposing them to harmful substances, invasive procedures, or restraining them. Excluded from this definition are close observation of natural behavior, temporary separation from social groups, and post-mortem examinations. The term "permanent retirement" for great apes means placing them in a sanctuary for lifetime care, where they will not be used in invasive research. This includes post-mortem examinations not done for research purposes and necessary physical exams by a licensed veterinarian for the well-being of the ape, its social group, or the species. The term "person" includes individuals, entities, and government bodies. A "suitable sanctuary" refers to a sanctuary system or privately funded sanctuary. A suitable sanctuary can be a privately funded sanctuary approved by the Secretary of Health and Human Services. SEC. 4. PROHIBITIONS. No invasive research on great apes allowed, including breeding, possession, sale, or use of federal funds for such purposes. Individualized medical care exempted. SEC. 5. RETIREMENT. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will retire all great apes owned by the Federal Government used for breeding or research. Violators of this Act may face civil penalties up to $10,000 per violation. SEC. 7. SEVERABILITY.

If any provision in this Act is deemed invalid or unenforceable, it will not affect the other provisions, and the Act will be interpreted as if the invalid provisions were never included.

SEC. 8. EFFECTIVE DATES.

Prohibitions on research and funding will take effect within 3 years of enactment, while all other requirements will be effective immediately.
